London: printed by I. B. for Hugh Beeston, dwelling next the castle in Cornhill, 1633.

div.head: To my truest friend, my worthiest kinsman, John ford of Grays-inn, esquire.
div.p:
The title of this little work (May good cousin) is in sense but the argument of a dedication; which being in most writers a custom, in many a compliment, I question not but your clear knowledge of my intents, will in me read as the earnest of affection. My ambition herein aims at a fair flight, born up on the double wings of gratitude, for a received, and acknowledgement for a continued love. It is not so frequent to number many kinsmen, and amongst them some friends; as to presume on some friends, and amongst them little friendship. But in every fullness of these particulars, I do not more partake through you (My cousin) the delight, then enjoy the benefit of them. This inscription to your name, is only a faithful deliverance to memory of the truth of my respects to virtue, and to the equal
in honour with virtue, desert. The contempt thrown on studies of this kind, by such as dote on their own singularity, hath almost so outfaced invention, and prescribed judgement; that it is more safe, more wise, to be suspectedly silent, then modestly confident of opinion, herein. Let me be bold to tell the severity of censurers, how willingly I neglect their practice, so long as I digress from no becoming thankfulness. Accept then (My cousin) this witness to posterity of my constancy to your merits, for no ties of blood, no engagements of friendship shall more justly live a precedent, than the sincerity of both in the heart of

div.head: To my friend Mr. John ford.

lg.l: Unto this altar, rich with thy own spice,
I bring one grain, to thy love's sacrifice:
And boast to see thy flames ascending, while
Perfumes enrich our air from thy sweet pile.
Look here thou that hast malice to the stage,
And impudence enough for the whole age;
To read this tragedy, and thy own be next.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Departed the court.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: Such was the Duke's command.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: You're secretary to the state and him,
Great in his counsels, wise, and (I think) honest,
Have you, in turning over old records,
Read but one name descended of the house
Of Lelus, in his loyalty remiss?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: Never, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Why then should I now, now, when glorious peace
Triumphs in change of pleasures, be wiped off,
Like to a useless moth, from courtly ease:
And whither must I go?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: You have the open world before you.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Why then 'tis like I'm banished.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: Not so;
My warrant is only to command you from the court,
Within five hours to depart after notice taken,
And not to live within thirty miles of it,
until it be thought meet by his excellence
To call you back: now I have warned you, my lord,
At your peril be it if you disobey; I shall
Inform the Duke of your discontent. —

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Do, politician, do:
I scent the plot of this disgrace; 'tis Fiormonda, she,
That glorious widow, whose commanding check
Ruins my love; like foolish beasts, thus they
Find danger, that prey too near the lion's den.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My noble lord Roseilli!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Sir, the joy
I should have welcomed you with, is wrapped up
In clouds of my disgrace; yet, honoured sir,
Howsoever frowns of great ones cast me down,
My service shall pay tribute in my lowness,
To your uprising virtues.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sir, I know
You are so well acquainted with your own,
You need not flatter mine; trust me, my lord,
He be a suitor for you.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: And I'll second
My nephew's suit with importunity.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: You are, my lord Fernando, late returned
From travels; pray instruct me, since the voice
Of most supreme authority commands
My absence: I determine to bestow
Some time in learning languages abroad;
Perhaps the change of air may change in me
Remembrance of my wrongs at home: good sir
Inform me; say I meant to live in Spain,
What benefit of knowledge might I treasure?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Troth, sir, I'll freely speak as I have found:
In Spain you lose experience; 'tis a climate
Too hot to nourish arts; the nation proud,
And in their pride unsociable; the court
More pliable to glorify itself
then do a stranger grace; if you intend
To traffic like a merchant, 'twere a place
Might better much your trade; but as for me,
I soon took surfeit on it.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What for France?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: France I more praise and love; you are (My lord)
Yourself for horsemanship much famed; and there
You shall have many proofs to show your skill,
The French are passing courtly, ripe of wit,
Kind, but extreme dissemblers; you shall have
A Frenchman ducking lower than your knee,
At th' instant mocking even your very shoe-ties:
To give the country due, it is on earth
A paradise; and if you can neglect
Your own appropriaments, but praising that
In others, wherein you excel yourself,
You shall be much beloved there.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Yet, methought ,
I heard you and the Duchess, two nights since,
Discoursing of an island thereabouts
Called — let me think — 'twas —

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: England.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: That, pray sir,
You have been there, methought I heard you praise it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I'll tell you what I found there; men as neat,
As courtly as the French, but in condition
Quite opposite: put case that you (My lord)
Could be more rare on horseback than you are,
If there (As there are many) one excelled
You in your art, as much as you do others,
Yet will the English think, their own is nothing
Compared with you a stranger; in their habits
They are not more fantastic than uncertain:
In short, their fare abundance; manhood, beauty,
No nation can disparage but itself.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: My lord, you have much cased me, I resolve.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And whither are you bent?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: My lord for travel,
To speed for England.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No, my lord, you must not;
I have yet some private conference
To impart unto you for your good: at night
I'll meet you at my lord Petruchio's house,
Till then be secret.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Dares my cousin trust me?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Dare I, my lord! yes, 'less your fact were greater
Than a bold woman's spleen.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: The duke's at hand,
And I must hence, my service to your lordships.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Now nephew, as I told you, since the Duke
Hath held the reins of state in his own hand,
Much altered from the man he was before,
(As if he were transformed in his mind)
To soothe him in his pleasures, amongst whom
Is fond Ferentes; one whose pride takes pride
In nothing more than to delight his lust;
And he (With grief I speak it) hath, I fear,
Too much besotted my unhappy daughter,
My poor Colona; whom, for kindred's sake,
As you are noble, as you honour virtue,
Persuade to love herself: a word from you
May win her more than my entreaties or frowns.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Uncle, I'll do my best; mean time pray tell me
Whose mediation wrought the marriage
Betwixt the Duke and Duchess? who was agent?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: His roving eye, and her enchanting face,
The only dower nature had ordained
T'advance her to her bridebed: she was daughter
Unto a gentleman of Milan, no better;
Preferred to serve in the Duke of Millaine's court:
Where, for her beauty, she was greatly famed:
And passing late from thence to Monacho,
To visit there her uncle, Paul Baglione,
The abbot; fortune (Queen to such blind matches)
presents her to the Duke's eye, on the way
As he pursues the deer: in short, my lord,
He saw her, loved her, wooed her, won her, matched her,
No counsel could divert him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: She is fair.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: She is; and to speak truth, I think right noble
In her conditions.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: If when I should choose,
Beauty and virtue were the fee proposed,
I should not pass for parentage.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: The Duke doth come.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Let's break off talk: if ever, now
Good angel of my soul protect my truth.
sp.stage: Enter Duke, Biancha, Fiormonda, Nibrássa. Ferentes, Julia and D'avolos.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come my Biancha, revel in mine arms,
Whiles I, wrapped in my admiration, view
Lilies and roses growing in thy cheeks.
Fernando! o thou half myself! no joy
Could make my pleasures full without thy presence!
I am a monarch of felicity,
Proud in a pair of jewels, rich and beautiful;
A perfect friend, a wife above compare.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sir, if a man so low in rank, may hope
By loyal duty, and devoted zeal,
To hold a correspondence in friendship
With one so mighty as the Duke of Pavy,
My uttermost ambition is to climb
To those deserts may give the style of servant.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Of partner in my dukedom, in my heart,
As freely as the privilege of blood
Hath made them mine, Phillippo and Fernando
Shall be without distinction: look, Biancha,
On this good man; in all respects to him
Be as to me: only the name of husband,
And reverent observance of our bed
shall differ us in persons, else in soul
We are all one.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: I shall, in best of love,
Regard the bosom-partner of my lord.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Ferentes.

sp.speaker: Fere.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: You are one love's courtship,
He had some change of words; 'twere no lost labour
To stuste your table-books, the man speaks wisely.

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.l: I'm glad your highness is so pleasant.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Sister.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: My lord and brother.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You are too silent;
Quicken your sad remembrance: though the loss
Of your dead husband be of more account
Then slight neglect, yet 'tis a sin against
The state of princes to exceed a mean
In mourning for the dead.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Should form, my lord,
Prevail above affection? no, it cannot.
You have yourself here a right noble Duchess,
(Virtuous at least) and should your grace now pay
(Which heaven forbid) the debt you owe to nature,
I dare presume, she'd not so soon forget
A prince that thus advanced her. — madam, could you?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: Bitter and shrewd.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Sister, I should too much bewray my weakness,
To give a resolution on a passion
I never felt nor feared.

sp.speaker: Nibr.
sp.l: A modest answer.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: If credit may be given to a face,
My lord, I'll undertake on her behalf;
Her words are trusty heralds to her mind.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Exceeding good; the man will undertake:
Observe it, Davolos.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: I do, lady; 'tis a smooth praise.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Friend, in thy judgement I approve thy love,
and love thee better for thy judging mine:
Though my gray-headed senate in the laws
Of strict opinion and severe dispute,
Would tie the limits of our free effects,
(Like superstitious Jews, to match with none
But in a tribe of princes like ourselves)
Gross nurtured slaves, who force their wretched souls
To crouch to profit; nay, for trash and wealth,
Dote on some crooked or mishapen form,
Hugging wise nature's lame deformity,
Begetting creatures ugly as themselves:
But why should princes do so, that command
The store-house of the earth's hid minerals?
No, my Biancha, thou art to me as dear
As if thy portion had been Europe's riches,
Since in thine eyes lies more than these are worth:
Set on; they shall be strangers to my heart
That envy thee thy fortunes:
Come, Fernando, my but divided self, what we have done
We are only debtor to heaven for. — on.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Now take thy time, or never, Davolos;
Prevail, and I will raise thee high in grace. —

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: Madam, I will omit no art,
My honoured lord Fernando.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To me, sir?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: Let me beseech your lordship
To excuse me, in the nobleness of your wisdom,
If I exceed good manners: I am one, my lord,
Who in the admiration of your perfect virtues,
Do so truly honour and reverence your deserts,
That there is not a creature bears life
Shall more faithfully study to do you service
In all offices of duty, and vows of due respect.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Good sir, you bind me to you: is this all?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: I beseech your care a little, good my lord; what I
Have to speak, concerns your reputation and best fortune.

sp.speaker: Fer,
sp.l: How's that? my reputation? lay aside
superfluous ceremony; speak, what is't?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: I do repute myself
The blessedest man alive, that I shall be the first
Gives your lordship news of your perpetual comfort.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: If singular beauty, unimitable virtues, honour, youth,
And absolute goodness be a fortune, all those are at once
Offered to your particular choice.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Without delays, which way?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: The great and gracious lady Fiormonda love you,
Infinitely loves you. — but, my lord, as ever you tendered
A servant to your pleasures, let me not be revealed, that
I gave you notice on't.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sure you are strangely out of tune, sir.

sp.speaker: R. Worser:
sp.l: Please but to speak to her, be but courtly ceremonious
With her, use once but the language of affection, if I
Misreport ought besides my knowledge, let me never
Have place in your good opinion: o, these women, my lord
Are as brittle mettle as your glasses, as smooth, as slippery:
Their very first substance was quicksands; let 'em look
Never so demurely, one Philip chokes them: my lord,
She loves you I know it. — but I beseech your lordship
Not to discover me; I would not for the world she
Should know that you know it by me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I understand you, and to thank your care
Will study to requite it; and I vow
She never shall have notice of your news
By me, or by my means. And, worthy sir,
Let me alike enjoin you not to speak
A word of that I understand her love;
And as for me, my word shall be your surety
I'll not as much as give her cause to think
I ever heard it.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: Nay, my lord,
Whatsoever I infer, you may break with her in it
If you please, for rather than silence should hinder
You one step to such a fortune, I will expose myself
to any rebuke for your sake, my good lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You shall not, indeed sir, I am still your friend,
And will prove so; for the present I am forced
To attend the Duke, good hours befall ye, I must leave you.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: Gone already; 'sfoot I ha' marred all, this is worse and worse, he's as cold as hemlock; if her highness knows how I have gone to work, she'll thank me scurvily: a pox of all dull brains; I took the clean contrary course: there is a mystery in this slight carelessness of his, I must sift it, and I will find it. ud's me, fool myself out of my wit: well, I'll choose some fitter opportunity to inveigle him, and till then, smooth her up, that he is a man overjoyed with the report. — — —

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.p: Madam, by this light I vow myself your servant; only yours, inespecially yours: time, like a turncoat, may order and disorder the outward fashions of our bodies, but shall never enforce a change on the constancy of my mind, sweet Colona, fair Colona, young and sprightful lady, do not let me in the best of my youth, languish in my earnest affections.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Why should you seek, my lord, to purchase glory
By the disgrace of a silly maid?

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.p: That I confess too;

I am every way so unworthy of the first fruits of thy embraces, so far beneath the riches of thy merit, that it can be no honour to thy fame, to rank me in the number of thy servants, yet prove me how true, how firm I will stand to thy pleasures, to thy command; and as time shall serve be ever thine now prithee dear Colona.

sp.speaker: Col,
sp.l: Well, well, my lord, I have no heart of flint;
Or if I had, you know by cunning words
How to outwear it. — but.

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.l: But what? do not pity thy own gentleness,
Lovely Colona; shall I speak? shall I? say
but I, and our wishes are made up.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: How shall I say I, when my fears say no?

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.l: You will not fail to meet two hours hence, sweet.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: No; yes, yes, I would have said, how my tongue trips.

sp.speaker: Fere.
sp.l: I take that promise, and that double yes as an assurance
Of thy faith, in the grove (Good sweet remember)
In any case alone (D'ye mark love) not as much as your
Duchess little dog, (You'll not forget) two hours hence,
(Think on't, and miss not,) till then —

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: O, if you should prove false, and love another?

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.l: Defy me then; I'll be all thine, and a servant
Only to thee, only to thee. — —
Very passing good, three honest women in our courts
Here of Italy, are enough to discredit a whole nation
Of that sex: he that is not a cuckold, or a bastard,
Is a strangely happy man; for a chaste wife, or a mother
That never stepped awry, are wonders, wonders in Italy.
'Slife I have got the feat on't, and am every day
More active in my trade; 'tis a sweet sin, this slip
Of mortality, and I have tasted enough for one
Passion of my senses: here comes more work for me:
And how does my own Julia, mew upon this sadness?
What's the matter you are melancholy?
Whither away, wench?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis well, the time has been when your smooth tongue
Would not have mocked my griefs, and had I been more
Chary of mine honour, you had still been lowly as you were.

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.l: Lowly? why I am sure I cannot be much more lowly
Than I am to thee, thou bringest me on my bare knees
Wench, twice in every four and twenty hours, besides
Half turns instead of bevers; what must we next
Do, sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Break vows on your side, I expect no other,
But every day look when some newer choice
May violate your honour and my trust.

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.l: Indeed forsooth, how they by that la, I hope I neglect
no opportunity to your nunquam satis, to be called
In question for; go, thou art as fretting as an old
Grogrum, by this hand I love thee for't, it becomes thee
So prettily to be angry: well, if thou shouldst die,
Farewell all love with me for ever: go, I'll meet
Thee soon in thy ladies back lobby, I will, wench,
Look for me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: But shall I be resolved you will be mine?

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.l: All thine; I will reserve my best ability,
My heart, my honour, only to thee, only to thee:
Pity of my blood away, I hear company
Coming on: remember soon I am all thine,
I will live perpetually only to thee, away. —
'Sfoot I wonder about what time of the year
I was begotten; sure it was when the moon was
In conjunction, and all the other planets
Drunk at a morris-dance: I am haunted
Above patience, my mind is not as infinite to do,
As my occasions are proffered of doing: chastity! I am
An eunuch, if I think there be any such thing; or
If there be, 'tis amongst us men, for I never found it
In a woman, thoroughly tempted, yet: I have a shrewd hard
Task coming on, but let it pass: who comes now?
My lord, the Duke's friend! I will strive to be inward with
Him, my noble lord Fernando.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My lord Ferentes, I should change some words
Of consequence with you; but since I am,
For this time, busied in more serious thoughts,
I'll pick some fitter opportunity.

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.l: I will wait your pleasure, my lord, — good day to
Your lordship. — — —

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Traitor to friendship, whither shall I run,
That lost to reason cannot sway the float
Of the unruly faction in my blood?
The Duchess, o the Duchess! in her smiles
Are all my joys abstracted; death to my thoughts,
my other plague comes to me.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: My lord Fernando, what, so hard at study?
You are a kind companion to yourself,
That love to be alone so.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Madam, no;
I rather chose this leisure to admire
The glories of this little world, the court,
Where like so many stars on several thrones,
Beauty and greatness shine in proper orbs,
Sweet matter for my meditation.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: So, so, sir, (Leave us Julia) your own proof
By travel and prompt observation,
Instruct you how to place the use of speech;
But since you are at leisure, pray let's sit;
We'll pass the time a little in discourse:
What have you seen abroad?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No wonders, lady,
Like these I see at home.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: At home! as how?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Your pardon, if my tongue (The voice of truth)
Report but what is warranted by sight.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: What sight?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Look in your glass, and you shall see
A miracle.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: What miracle?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Your beauty,
So far above all beauties else abroad,
As you are in your own, superlative.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Fie, fie, your wit hath too much edge.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Would that,
Or any thing, that I could challenge mine,
Were but of value to express how much
I serve in love the sister of my prince.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: 'Tis for your prince's sake then, not for mine.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: For you in him, and much for him in you.
I must acknowledge, madam, I observe
in your affects a thing to me most strange,
Which makes me so much honour you the more.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Pray tell it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Gladly, lady:
I see how opposite to youth and custom
You set before you in your tabulature
Of your remembrance, the becoming griefs
Of a most loyal lady; for the loss
Of so renowned a prince as was your lord.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Now good my lord, no more of him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Of him!
I know it is a needless task in me
To set him forth in his deserved praise,
You better can record it; for you find
How much more he exceeded other men
In most heroic virtues of account,
So much more was your loss in losing him.
Of him! his praise should be a field too large,
Too spacious, for so mean an orator
As I, to range in.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Sir, enough; 'tis true,
He well deserved your labour; on his deathbed
This ring he gave me, bade me never part
With this, but to the man I loved as dear
As I loved him; yet since you know which way
To blaze his worth so rightly, in return
To your deserts, wear this for him and me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: 'Tis yours.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Methought you said, he charged you
Not to impart it but to him you loved
As dear as you loved him.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: True, I said so.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O then far be it, my unhallowed hand
With any rude intrusion should unveil
A testament enacted by the dead.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Why man, that testament is disannulled,
and cancelled quite by us that live: look here,
My blood is not yet freezed; for better instance
Be judge yourself, experience is no danger:
Cold are my sighs; but feel, my lips are warm.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What means the virtuous marquess?

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: To new kiss
The oath to thee, which whiles he lived was his:
Hast thou yet power to love?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To love?

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: To meet
Sweetness of language in discourse as sweet.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Madam, 'twere dulness, passed the ignorance
Of common block heads, not to understand
Whereto this favour tends; and 'tis a fortune
So much above my fate, that I could wish
No greater happiness on earth; but know,
Long since, I vowed to live a single life.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: What was't you said?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I said I made a vow.
Blessed deliverance!

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Prevented? mischief on this interruption.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: My lord Fernando you encounter fitly,
I have a suit t'ee.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Tis my duty, madam,
To be commanded.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Since my lord the Duke
Is now disposed to mirth, the time serves well
For mediation, that he would be pleased
To take the lord Roseilli to his grace,
He is a noble gentleman: I dare
Engage my credit, loyal to the state:
And, sister, one that ever strove ( methought )
By special service, and obsequious care,
To win respect from you; it were a part
Of gracious favour, if you pleased to join
With us, in being suitors to the Duke
for his return to court.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: To court! indeed
You have some cause to speak; he undertook
Most championlike to win the prize at tilt,
In honour of your picture. — marry did he:
There's not a groom o'th querry, could have matched
The jolly riding man; pray get him back,
I do not need his service, madam, I.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Not need it, sister? why? I hope you think
'Tis no necessity in me to move it,
More than respect of honour.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Honour? puh,
Honour is talked of more than known by some.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Sister, these words I understand not.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Swell not unruly thoughts:
Madam, the motion you propose, proceeds
From the true touch of goodness; 'tis a plea
Wherein my tongue and knee shall jointly strive
To beg his highness for Roseillie's cause:
Your judgement rightly speaks him; there is not
In any court of Christendom, a man
For quality or trust more absolute.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: How? is't even so?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I shall for ever bless
Your highness for your gracious kind esteems
Of my dishartned kinsman; and to add
Encouragement to what you undertake,
I dare affirm, 'tis no important fault
Hath caused the Duke's distaste.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: I hope so too.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: Let your highness, and you all, my lords, take advice
How you motion his excellency on Roseillie's behalf:
There is more danger in that man than is fit to be
Publicly reported; I could wish things were other wise
For his own sake; but I'll assure ye, you will exceedingly
Alter his excellency's disposition (He now is in) if you but
Mention the name of Roseilli to his ear; I am so much
acquainted in the process of his actions.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: If it be so, I am the sorrier, sir:
I'm loath to move my lord unto offence,
Yet I'll adventure chiding.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O had I India's gold, I'd give it all
To exchange one private word, one minutes breath
With this heart-wounding beauty.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Prithee no more, Ferentes, by the faith
I owe to honour, thou hast made me laugh
Beside my spleen; Fernando, hadst thou heard
The pleasant humour of Maurucio's dotage
Discoursed, how in the winter of his age
He is become a lover, thou wouldst swear
A morris-dance were but a tragedy
Compared to that: well, we will see the youth:
What council hold you now, sirs?

sp.speaker: Bia.
sp.l: We, my lord, were talking of the horsemanship in France
Which, as your friend reports, he thinks exceeds
All other nations.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How? why, have not we
As gallant riders here?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: None that I know.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Pish, your affection leads you; I dare
Wage a thousand ducats not a man in France
Outrides Roseilli.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: I shall quit this wrong.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: I said as much, my lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I have not seen
His practice, since my coming back.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Where is he?
How is't we see him not?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: What's this? what's this?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I hear he was commanded from the court.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: O confusion on this villainous occasion.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: True; but we meant a day or two at most,
Should be his furthest term; not yet returned?
Where's D'avolos?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You know our minds,
How comes it thus to pass, we miss Roseilli.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: My lord, in a sudden discontent I hear he departed towards Benevento, determining (As I am given to understand) to pass to Seville, minding to visit his cousin don Pedro de Toledo, in the Spanish court.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The Spanish court! now by the blessed bones
Of good s. Francis, let there posts be sent
To call him back, or I will post thy head
Beneath my foot; ha! you, you know my mind,
Look that you get him back; the Spanish court,
And without our commission, — say!

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Here's fine juggling.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Good sir be not so moved.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Fie, fie, Biancha;
'Tis such a gross indignity, I'd rather
Have lost seven years revenue. — the Spanish court!
How now, what ails our sister?

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: On the sudden
I fall a bleeding, 'tis an ominous sign;
Pray heaven it turn to good. — your highness leave. —

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Look to her; come Fernando, come Biancha,
Let's strive to overpass this choleric heat:
Sirrah, see that you trifle not. How we,
Who sway the manage of authority,
May be abused by smooth officious agents?
But look well to our sister. — —

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Nephew, please you
To see your friend tonight ?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yes, uncle, yes:
Thus bodies walk unsold; mine eyes but follows
My heart entombed in yonder goodly shrine:
Life without her, is but death's subtle snares,
And I am but a coffin to my cares.

sp.stage: Enter Maurucio looking in a glass, trimming his beard; Giacopo brushing him.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: Beard be confined to neatness, that no hair
May stover up to prick my mistress lip,
More rude than bristles of a porcupine.
Giacopo.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: Am I all sweet behind?

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.l: I have no poulterer's nose, but your apparel sits
About you most debonairely.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: But Giacopo, with what grace do my words proceed out of my mouth? have I a moving countenance? is there harmony in my voice? canst thou perceive, as it were, a handsomeness of shape in my very breath, as it is formed into syllable, Giacopo?
sp.stage: Enter Duke, lords and ladies above.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.p: Yes indeed, sir, I do feel a savour as pleasant as — a glister-pipe, — — calamus or Civet.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Observe him and be silent.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Hold thou the glass, Giacopo, and mark me with what exceeding comeliness I could court the lady marquess if it come to the push.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Sister, you are his aim.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: A subject fit
To be the stall of laughter.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: That's your music.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Thus I reverse my pace, and thus stalkingly in courtly gate I advance, one, two, and three. — good, I kiss my hand, make my congee, settle my countenance, and thus begin. — hold up the glass higher, Giacopo.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.l: Thus high, sir?

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: 'Tis well, now mark me:
most excellent marquess, most fair lady,
Let not old age, or hairs that are silver
Disparage my desire; for it may be
I am then other green youth nimbler:
Since I am your grace's servant so true,
Great lady than love me for my virtue.
O Giacopo! Petrarch was a dunce, dante's a jig-maker,
S'anazar a goose, and Ariosto a puckfist to me:
I tell thee, Giacopo, I am wrapped with fury,
And have been for these six nights together
Drunk with the pure liquor of Helicon.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.l: I think no less, sir;
For you look as wild, and talk as idly
As if you had not slept these nine years.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What think you of this language, sister?

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Sir, I think, in princes' courts, no age nor greatness
But must admit the fool; in me 'twere folly
To scorn what greater states than I have been.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: O, but you are too general.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: A fool;
I thank your highness; many a woman's wit
Have thought themselves much better, was much worse.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: You still mistake me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Silence, note the rest.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: God-a-mercy brains; Giocopo, I have it.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.l: What? my lord?

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: A conceit, Giacopo, and a fine one; down on thy knees, Giocopo, and worship my wit; give me both thy ears: thus it is, I will have my picture drawn most composituously in a squire table of some too foot long, from the crown of the head to the waste downward, no further.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.p: Then you'll look like a dwarf, sir, being cut off by the middle.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p:
Speak not thou, but wonder at the conceit that follows; in my bosom on my left side. I will have a lease of blood-red crimson velvet (As it were part of my doublet) open; which being opened, Giacopo, (Now mark) I will
have a clear and most transparent crystal in the form of a heart. — (Singular admirable.) When I have framed this, I will, as some rare outlandish piece of workmanship, bestow it on the most fair and illustrious lady Fiormonda.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.l: But now, sir, for the conceit.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Simplicity and ignorance, prate no more: blockhead, dost not understand yet? why this being to her instead of a looking-glass, she shall no oftener powder her hair, surfell her cheeks, cleanse her teeth, or conform the hairs of her eyebrows, but having occasion to use this glass (Which for the rareness and richness of it, she will hourly do) but she shall as often gaze on my picture, remember me, and behold the excellence of her excellency's beauty, in the prospective and mirror, as it were, in my heart.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.l: I marry, sir, this is something.
All above. Ha, ha, ha. — —

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: My sister's gone in anger.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: Who's that laughs? search with thine eyes, Giacopo.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.p: O my lord, my lord, you have gotten an everlasting fame; the Duke's grace, and the Duchess grace, and my lord Fernando's grace, with all the rabble of courtiers, have heard every word, look where they stand: now you shall be made a count for your wit, and I lord for my counsel.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be shrew the chance, we are discovered.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: Pity, — o my wisdom! I must speak to them.
O Duke most great, and most renowned Duchess!
Excuse my apprehension, which not much-is:
'Tis love, my lord, that's all the hurt you see,
Angelica herself plead for me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We pardon you, most wise and learned lord,
And that we may all glorify your wit,
Entreat your wisdom's company today,
To grace our talk with your grave discourse:
What says your mighty eloquence?

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Giacopo, help me; his grace has put me out my own bias, and I know not what to answer in form.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.l: Ud's me, tell him you'll come.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: Yes, I will come, my lord the Duke, I will.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We take your word, and wish your honour health.
Away then; come Biancha, we have found
A salve for melancholy. Mirth and ease. —

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: I'll see the jolly lover and his glass
Take leave of one another.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: Are they gone?

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.l: O my lord, I do now smell news.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: What news, Giacopo?

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.p: The Duke has a smackering towards you, and you shall clap up with his sister, the widow, suddenly.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: She is mine, Giacopo, she is mine; advance the glass, Giacopo, that I may practise as I pass, to walk a portly grace like a marquess; to which degree I am now a climbing.
Thus do we march to honour's haven of bliss,
To ride in triumph through Persepolis.
sp.stage: Exit Gia, going backeward with the glass, Mau. complementing.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Now, as I live,
Here's laughter worthy our presence;
I will not lose him so. — —

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: To me, my lord!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Please but to hear
The story of a castaway in love;
And o let not the passage of a jest
Make slight a sadder subject, who hath placed
All happiness in your diviner eyes.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: My lord, the time — —

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The time! yet hear me speak,
For I must speak or burst: I have a soul
So anchored down with cares in seas of woe,
That passion, and the vows I owe to you,
Have changed me to a lean anatomy,
Sweet Princess of my life —

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Forbear, or I shall —

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yet as you honour virtue, do not freeze
My hopes to more discomfort, then as yet
My fears suggest; no beauty so adorns
The composition of a well-built mind,
As pity: hear me out.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: No more; I spare
To tell you what you are; and must confess,
Do almost hate my judgement, that it once
Thought goodness dwelled in you: remember now
It is the third time since your treacherous tongue
Hath pleaded treason to my care and fame;
Yet for the friendship 'twixt my lord and you,
I have not voiced your follies; if you dare
To speak a fourth time, you shall rue your lust:
'Tis all no better; learn, and love yourself.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Gone! o my sorrows! how am I undone?
Not speak again? no, no, in her chaste breast
Virtue and resolution have discharged
All female weakness: I have sued and sued,
Kneeled, wept, and begged; but tears, and vows, and words,
Move her no more than summer-winds a rock:
I must resolve to check this rage of blood,
And will; she is all icy to my fires,
Yet even that ye inflames in me desires.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Is't possible the Duke should be so moved?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: 'Tis true; you have no enemy at court
But her, for whom you pine so much in love:
Then master your affections; I am sorry you hug your ruin so.
What say you to the project I proposed?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I entertain it, with a greater joy
Than shame can check.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You are come as I could wish, my cousin is resolved.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Without delay
Prepare yourself, and meet at court anon,
Some half hour hence; and Cupid bless your joy,

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Is ever man was bounden to a friend —

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No more; away: love's rage is yet unknown,
In his (Ay me) too well, I feel my own:
So, now I am alone, now let me think;
She is the Duchess; say she be: a creature
Sowed up in painted cloth, might so be styled,
That's but a name; she's married too, she is,
And therefore better might distinguish love:
She's young, and fair; why, madam, that's the bait
Invites me more to hope; she's the Duke's wife;
Who knows not this? she's bosomed to my friend:
There, there, I am quite lost: will not be won;
Still worse and worse; abhors to hear me speak:
Eternal mischief, I must urge no more:
For were I not belopered in my soul,
Here were enough to quench the flames of hell.
What then? pish, I must not speak, I'll write.
Come then, sad secretary to my plaints,
Plead thou my faith, for words are turned to sighs.
What says this paper? — he reads to himself.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: Now is the time; alone; reading a letter; good; how now? striking his breast? what, in the name of policy, should this mean? tearing his hair? passion, by all the hopes of my life, plain passion: now I perceive it; if this be not a fit of some violent affection, I am an ass in understanding; why 'tis plain, plainer and plainer: love in the extremest: o for the party, who now? the greatness of his spirits is to high cherished to be caught with some ordinary stuff, and if it be my lady Fiormonda, I am strangely mistook: well, that I have fit occasion soon to understand: I have here two pictures, newly drawn, to be sent for a present to the abbot of Monacho, the Duchess uncle, her own and my ladies: I'll observe which of these may, perhaps, bewray him: — 'a turns about, my noble lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You're welcome, sir, I thank you

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: Me, my lord? for what, my lord?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Who's there? I cry you mercy, D'avolos,
I took you for another, pray excuse me;
What is't you bear there?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: No secret, my lord, but may be imparted to you:
A couple of pictures, my good lord, please you see them.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I care not much for pictures: but whose are they?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: Th'one is for my lord's sister, the other is the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ha, D'avolos, the Duchess's?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: Yes, my lord: — sure the word startled him —
— observe that.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You told me, master secretary, once,
You owed me love.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: Service, my honoured lord, howsoever you please to term it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Twere rudeness to be suitor for a sight,
Yet trust me, sir, I'll be all secret.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: I beseech your lordship;
They are, as I am, constant to your pleasure:

This (My lord) is the widow marquess's, as it now newly came from the picture-drawers, the oil yet green a sweet picture; and in my judgement, art hath not been a niggard in striving to equal the life. Michael Angelo himself needed not blush to own the workmanship.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A very pretty picture;
But, kind signior, to whose use is it?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: For the Dukes, my lord, who determines to send it with all speed as a present to Paul Baglione, uncle to the Duchess; that he may see the riches of two such lustres as shine in the court of Pavy.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Pray sir, the other?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: This (My lord) is for the Duchess Biancha, a wondrous sweet picture, if you well observe with what singularity the artsman hath striven to set forth each limb in exquisitest proportion, not missing a hair.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A hair?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: She cannot more formally,

Or (If it may be lawful to use the word) more really, behold her own symmetry in her glass, then in taking a sensible view of this counterfeit: when I first saw it, I verily almost was of a mind that this was her very lip.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Lip!

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: How constantly he dwells upon this portraiture? Nay, I'll assure your lordship there is no defect of cunning. His eye is fixed as if it were incorporated there. — were not the party herself alive to witness that there is a creature composed of flesh and blood, as naturally enriched with such harmony of admiral beauty, as is here artificially counterfeited, a very curious eye might repute it as an imaginary rapture of some transported conceit, to aim at an impossibility; whose very first gaze is of force almost to persuade a substantial love in a settled heart.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Love! heart.

sp.speaker: R D.
sp.l: My honoured lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O heavens!

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: I am confirmed. — what ails your lordship?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You need not praise it, sir, itself is praise.
How near had I forgotten myself? — I thank you.
'Tis such a picture as might well become
The shrine of some feigned Venus; I am dazzled
With looking on't: — pray sir convey it hence.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: I am all your servant: — blessed, blessed discovery!
Please you to command me?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No, gentle sir: I'm lost beyond my senses.
D'ye hear sir, good where dwells the picture maker?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: By the castles farther drawbridge, near Galzazzo's statue; his name is Alphonso Trinultio — happy above all fate.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You say enough, my thanks t'ee.
Were that picture
But rated at my lordship, 'twere too cheap.
I fear I spoke or did I know not what,
All sense of providence was in mine eye.

sp.speaker: Fere.
sp.p:
Youth in threescore years and ten; trust me (My lord
Maurucio) you are now younger in the judgement of those that compare your former age with your latter, by seven and twenty years, than you were three years ago: by all my fidelity, 'tis a miracle: the ladies wonder at you.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: Let them wonder; I am wise, as I am courtly.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.p: The ladies, my lord, call him the green broom of the court, he sweeps all before him, and swear he has a stabbing wit: it is a very glister to laughter -

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: Nay, I know I can tickle 'em at my pleasure:
I am stiff and strong, Ferentes.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.l: A radish root is a spear of steel in comparison of
I know what. —

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.l: The marquess doth love you.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: She doth love me.

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.p: And begins to do you infinite grace. Maurucio, infinite grace.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I'll take this time:
Good hour, my lords, to both.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Right princely Fernando, the best of the Fernando's: by the pith of generation, the man I look for. His highness hath sent to find you out; he is determined to weather his own proper individual person, for two days' space, in my lord Nibrassa's forest, to hunt the deer, the buck, the roe, and eke the barren doe.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Is his highness preparing to hunt?

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.p: Yes, my lord, and resolved to lie forth for the breviating the prolixity of some superfluous transmigration of the sun's double cadence to the western horizon, my most perspicuous good lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O, sir, let me beseech you to speak in your own mother tongue — two days' absence — well — my lord Maurucio, I have a suit t'ee.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: My lord Fernando, I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: That you will accept from me a very choice token of my love, will you grant it?

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: Will you grant mine?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Only to know what the suit is, you please to prefer to me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why 'tis, my lord, a fool.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: A fool?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: As very a fool
As your lordship is — hopeful to see in any time of your life.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.p: Now good my lord part not with the fool on any terms.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: I beseech you, my lord, has the fool qualities?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Very rare ones:

You shall not hear him speak one wise word in a month's converse; passing temperate of diet, for keep him from meat four and twenty hours, and he will fast a whole day and a night together: unless you urge him to swear, there seldom comes an oath from his mouth: and of a fool, my lord, to tell ye the plain truth, had a' but half as much wit as you, my lord, he would be in short time three quarters as arrant wise as your lordship.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Giacopo, these are very rare elements in a creature of little understanding: o, that I long to see him.
sp.stage: Enter Petruchio, and Roseilli like a fool.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A very harmless idiot,
And as you could wish, look where he comes.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Nephew, here is the thing you sent for:
Come hither fool, come 'tis a good fool.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here, my lord,
I freely give you the fool, pray use him well for my sake.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: I take the fool most thankfully at your hands, my lord: hast any qualities, my pretty fool? wilt dwell with me?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: A, a, a, a, I.

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.l: I never beheld a more natural creature in my life.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Uncle, the Duke I hear prepares to hunt:
Let's in and wait. Farewell Maurucio. —

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: Beast that I am, not to ask the fool's name:
'Tis no matter, fool is a sufficient title to call
the greatest lord in the court by, if he be no wiser than he.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.p: O my lord, what an arrant excellent pretty creature 'tis? come honey, honey, honey, come.

sp.speaker: Fere.
sp.l: You are beholding to my lord Fernando for this gift.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: True; o that he could but speak methodically!
Canst speak, fool?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Can speak; de e e e e —

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.p: 'Tis a present for an emperor: what an excellent instrument were this to purchase a suit, or a monopoly from the Duke's ear?

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: I have it, I am wise and fortunate; Giacopo, I will leave all conceits, and instead of my picture, offer the lady marquess this mortal man of weak brain.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.l: My lord you have most rarely bethought you;
For so shall she no oftener see the fool,
But she shall remember you better,
Then by a thousand looking-glasses.

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.l: She will most graciously entertain it.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: I may tell you, Ferentes, there's not a great woman amongst forty, but knows how to make sport with a fool. Dost know how old thou art, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Dud — a clap cheek for noun's sake gaffer. H ee e e e e.

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.p: Alas, you must ask him no questions; but clap him on the cheek: I understand his language; your fool is though tender heartedest creature that is.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: No more, thou hast, in this discovery,
Exceeded all my favours, D'avolos.
Is't mistress madam Duchess? brave revenge.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: But had your grace seen the infinite appetite of lust in the piercing adultery of his eye, you would —

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Or change him, or confound him, prompt dissembler!
Is here the bond of his religious vow?
And that, now when the Duke is rid abroad,
My gentleman will stay behind, is sick — or so.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: Not altogether in health, it was the excuse he made.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: Most fit opportunity:
her grace comes just i'th nick; let me study.

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.l: Lose no time, my lord.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.l: To her, sir.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: Vouchsafe to stay thy foot, most Cynthian hue.
And from a creature, ever vowed thy servant,
Accept this gift; most rare, most fine, most new,
The earnest penny of a love so servant.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: What means the jolly youth?

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Nothing, sweet Princess,
But only to present your grace with this sweet faced fool: please you to accept him to make you merry; I'll assure your grace, he is a very whole some fool.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: A fool? you might as well ha' given yourself:
Whence is he?

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Now, just very now, given me out of special favour, by the lord Fernando, madam.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: By him? well, I accept him; thank you for't:
And in requital, take that tooth picker.
'Tis yours.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: A tooth-picker; I kiss your bounty: no quibble now?
And madam,
If I grow sick, to make my spirits quicker,
I will revive them with this sweet tooth-picker.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Make use on't as you list; here D'avolos,
Take in the fool.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: Come, sweet heart, wilt along with me?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: V v umh — v v umh — won not, won not — v v umh

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Wilt go with me, chick?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Will go, te e e — go will go —

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Come D'avolos, observe tonight ; 'tis late:
Or I will win my choice, or curse my fate.

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.p: This was wisely done now: 'sfoot you purchase a favour from a creature, my lord, the greatest King of the earth would be proud of.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: Giacopo!

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Come behind me, Giacopo; I am big with conceit and must be delivered of poetry, in the eternal commendation of this gracious tooth-picker: but first, I hold it a most healthy policy to make a flight supper.
For meat's the food that must preserve our lives,
And now's the time, when mortals whet their knives on thresholds, shoe-soles, cartwheels, etc. Away Giacopo.
sp.stage: Enter Colona with lights, Biancha, Fiormonda, Julia, Fernando, and D'avolos; Colona placeth the lights on a table, and sets down a chessboard.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: 'Tis yet but early night, too soon to sleep:
Sister, shall's have a mate at chess?

sp.speaker: Fior,
sp.l: A mate!
No, madam; you are grown too hard for me:
My lord Fernando is a fitter match.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: He's a well practised gamester:
Well, I care not, how cunning so ere he be,
To pass an hour; I'll try your skill, my lord;
Reach here the chessboard.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: Are you so apt to try his skill, madam Duchess?
Very good.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I shall bewray too much my ignorance
In striving with your highness; 'tis a game
I lose at still, by oversight.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Well, well, I fear you not, let's to't.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: You need not, madam.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: Marry needs she not; how gladly will she to't? 'tis a rook to a Queen, she heaves a pawn to a knight's place; by’r lady, if all be truly noted, to a Duke's place; and that's beside the play, I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Madam, I must entreat excuse; I feel
The temper of my body not in case
To judge the strife.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Lights for our sister, sirs:
Good rest t'ee; I'll but end my game and follow.
sp.stage: Fiormrnda takes her leave, attended by D'avolos and Julia: as she goes out, she speaks to D'avolos. —

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Let 'em have time enough, and as thou canst,
Be near to hear their courtship, D'avolos.

sp.speaker: R, D.
sp.l: Madam, I shall observe 'em with all cunning secrecy.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Colona, attend our sister to her chamber.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I shall madam. —
sp.stage: Exit fior. Col. Jul. and R. D.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Play.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I must not lose th'advantage of the game:
Madam, your Queen is lost.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: My clergy help me;
My Queen! and nothing for it but a pawn?
Why then the game's lost too; but play.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What madam?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: You must needs play well,
You are so studious. —
Fie upon't, you study passed patience: —
What d'ye dream on? here's demurring
Would weary out a statue. — good now play.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Forgive me, let my knees for ever stick
Nailed to the ground, as earthy as my fears;
Ere I arise, to part away so cursed
In my unbounded anguish, as the rage
Of flame's, beyond all utterance of words,
Devour me; lightened by your sacred eyes.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: What means the man?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To lay before your feet
In lowest vassalage, the bleeding heart
That sighs the tender of a suit disdained.
Great lady pity me, my youth, my wounds,
And do not think, that I have culled this time
From motions swiftest measure, to unclasp
The book of lust; if purity of love
Have residence in virtue's quest; lo here,
Bent lower in my heart than on my knee,
I beg compassion to a love, as chaste
As softness of desire can intimate.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: At it already? admirable haste.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Am I again betrayed? — bad man.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Keep in
Bright angel, that severer breath, to cool
That heat of cruelty, which sways the temple
Of your too stony breast; you cannot urge
One reason to rebuke my trembling plea,
Which I have not, with many night's expense,
Examined; but, oh madam, still I find
No physic strong to cure a tortured mind,
But freedom from the torture it sustains.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: Not kissing yet? still on your knees? O for a plump bed and clean sheets, to comfort the aking of his shins! We shall have 'em clip anon, and lisp kisses; here's ceremony with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Rise up, we charge you, rise; look on our face.
What see you there that may persuade a hope
Of lawless love? Know, most unworthy man,
So much we hate the baseness of thy lust,
As were none living of thy sex but thee,
We had much rather prostitute our blood
To some envenomed serpent, then admit
Thy bestial dalliance: couldst thou dare to speak
Again, when we forbade? no, wretched thing,
Take this for answer; if thou henceforth open
Thy leprous mouth to tempt our ear again,
We shall not only certify our lord
Of thy disease in friendship, but revenge
Thy boldness with the forfeit of thy life.
Think on't.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: Now, now, now the game is a foot, your grey jennet with the white face is curried, forsooth; please your lordship leap up into the saddle, forsooth; — poor Duke, how does thy head ache now?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Stay, go not hence in choler, blessed woman!
You've schooled me, lend me hearing; though the float
of infinite desires swell to a tide
Too high so soon to ebb, yet by this hand,
This glorious gracious hand of yours —

sp.speaker: R, D.
sp.l: I marry, the match is made, clap hands and to't ho.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I swear,
Henceforth I never will as much in word,
In letter, or in syllable, presume
To make a repetition of my grief
Good night t'ee: if when I am dead you rip
This coffin of my heart, there shall you read
With constant eyes, what now my tongue defines,
Biancha's name carved out in bloody lines.
For ever, lady, now good night.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Good night:
Rest in your goodness; lights there; sir good night.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: So, via — to be cuckold (Mercy and providence) is as natural to a married man, as to eat sleep or wear a nightcap. Friends! I will rather trust mine arm in the throat of a lion, my purse with a courtesan, my neck with the chance on a die, or my religion in a synagogue of Jews, than my wife with a friend; wherein do princes exceed the poorest peasant that ever was yoked to a sixpenny strumpet, but that the horns of the one are mounted some two inches higher by a chopine than the other? o Actaeon! the goodliest headed beast of the forest, amongst wild cattle, is a stag; and the goodliest beast amongst tame fools in a corporation is a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Speak D'avolos, how thrives intelligence?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: Above the prevention of fate, madam: I saw him kneel make pitiful faces, kiss hands and forefingers, rise and by this time he is up, up madam: doubtless the youth aims to be Duke, for he is gotten into the Duke's seat an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Is't true?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p:
Oracle, oracle; siege was laid, parley admitted, composition
offered, and the fort entered; there's no interruption, the Duke will be at home tomorrow (Gentle animal) what d'ye resolve?

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: To stir up tragedies as black as brave;
And sending the lecher panting to his grave. —
sp.stage: Enter biancha, her hair about her ears, in her night mantle; she draws a curtain, where Fernando is discovered in bed, sleeping, she sets down the Candle before the bed, and goes to the bed side.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Resolve, and do; 'tis done, what, are those eyes
Which lately were so overdrowned in tears,
So easy to take rest? O happy man!
How sweetly sleep hath sealed up sorrows here?
But I will call him: what? My lord, my lord,
My lord Fernando.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Who calls me?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: My lord,
Sleeping or waking?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ha! who is't?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: 'Tis I:
Have you forgotten my voice? or is your ear
But useful to your eye?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Madam, the Duchess?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: She, 'tis she; sit up,
Sit up and wonder, whiles my sorrows swell:
The nights are short, and I have much to say.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Is't possible, 'tis you?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: 'Tis possible;
Why do you think I come?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why! to crown joys,
And make me master of my best desires.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: 'Tis true, you guess aright; sit up and listen.
With shame and passion now I must confess,
Since first mine eyes beheld you, in my heart
You have been only King; if there can be
A violence in love, than I have felt
That tyranny; be record to my soul,
the justice which I for this folly fear:
Fernando, in short words, howe'er my tongue
Did often chide thy love, each word thou spak'st
Was music to my ear; was never poor
Poor wretched woman lived, that loved like me;
So truly, so unfeignedly.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O madam —

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: To witness that I speak is truth, — look here,
Thus singly I adventure to thy bed,
And do confess my weakness; if thou temptest
My bosom to thy pleasures, I will yield.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Perpetual happiness!

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Now hear me out:
When first Caraffa, Pavy's Duke, my lord,
Saw me, he loved me; and without respect
Of dower, took me to his bed and bosom,
Advanced me to the titles I possess;
Not moved by counsel, or removed by greatness,
Which to requite, betwixt my soul and heaven,
I vowed a vow to live a constant wife;
I have done so: nor was there in the world
A man created, could have broke that truth
For all the glories of the earth, but thou;
But thou, Fernando: do I love thee now?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Beyond imagination.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: True, I do,
Beyond imagination: if no pledge
Of love can instance what I speak is true,
But loss of my best joys, here, here, Fernando,
Be satisfied, and ruin me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: To give my body up to thy embraces,
A pleasure that I never wished to thrive in,
Before this fatal minute: mark me now;
If thou dost spoil me of this robe of shame,
By my best comforts, here I vow again,
To thee, to heaven, to the world, to time,
ere yet the morning shall new Christen day,
I'll kill myself.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: How madam, how?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: I will:
Do what thou wilt, 'tis in thy choice; what say ye?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Pish, do you come to try me? tell me, first,
Will you but grant a kiss?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Yes, take it; that,
Or what thy heart can wish: I am all thine.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O me — come, come, how many women pray
Were ever heard or read of, granted love,
And did as you protest you will?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Fernando;
Jest not at my calamity: I kneel: —
By these disheveled hairs, these wretched tears,
By all that's good, if what I speak, my heart
Vows not eternally, then think, my lord,
Was never man sued to me I denied,
Think me a common and most cunning whore,
And let my sins be written on my grave,
My name rest in reproof. — do as you list

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I must believe ye, yet I hope anon,
When you are parted from me, you will say
I was a good cold easy-spirited man:
Nay, laugh at my simplicity; say, will ye?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: No by the faith I owe my bridal vows:
But ever hold thee much much dearer far
Than all my joys on earth, by this chaste kiss.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You have prevailed, and heaven forbid that I
Should by a want on appetite profane
This sacred temple; 'tis enough for me
You'll please to call me servant.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Nay, be thine:
Command my power, my bosom; and I'll write
This love within the tables of my heart.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Enough; I'll master passion, and triumph
In being conquered; adding to it this,
in you my love, as it begun, shall end.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: The latter I new vow — but day comes on,
What now we leave unfinished of content,
Each hour shall perfect up: sweet, let's part.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: This kiss, — best life good rest.

sp.speaker: Bian,
sp.l: All mine to thee.
Remember this, and think I speak thy words:
When I am dead, rip up my heart and read
With constant eyes, what now my tongue defines,
Fernando's name carved out in bloody lines.
Once more good rest, sweet.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Your most faithful servant.

sp.stage: Enter Nibrassa chasing, after him Julia weeping

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Get from me, strumpet, in famous whore, leprosy of my blood, make thy moan to ballad singers, and rhymers, they'll jig out thy wretchedness and abominations to new tunes; as for me, I renounce thee, thou'rt no daughter of mine, I disclaim the legitimation of thy birth, and curse the hour of thy nativity.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Pray sir vouchsafe me hearing.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.l: With child I shame to my grave!
O whore, wretched beyond utterance or reformation!
What wouldst say?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sir, by the honour of my mother's hearse,
He has protested marriage, pledged his faith:
If vows have any force, I am his wife.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: His faith?
Why thou fool, thou wickedly credulous fool,

Canst thou imagine luxury is observant of religion? No, no, it is with a frequent lecher as usual to for swear as to swear, their piety is in making idolatry a worship, their
hearts and their tongues are as different as thou (Thou whore) and a virgin.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You are too violent, his truth will prove
His constancy, and so excuse my fault.

sp.speaker: Nibr.
sp.p: Shameless woman! this belief will damn thee: how will thy lady marquess justly reprove me, for preferring to her service a monster of so lewd and impudent a life? Look to't; if thy smooth devil leave thee to thy infamy, I will never pity thy mortal pangs, never lodge thee under my roof, never own thee for my child; mercy be my witness. —

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Hide not thy folly by unwise excuse.
Thou art undone, Colona; no entreaties,
No warning, no persuasion, could put off
The habit of thy dotage on that man
Of much deceit, Ferentes: would thine eyes
Had seen me in my grave, ere I had known
The stain of this thine honour.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Good my lord,
Reclaim your incredulity; my fault
Proceeds from lawful composition
Of wedlock; he hath sealed his oath to mine,
To be my husband.

sp.speaker: Nibr.
sp.p: Husband? heigh dam! is't even so? nay then we have partners in affliction: if my jolly gallants long clapper have struck on both sides, all is well: Petruchio, thou art not wise enough to be a parator; come hither man, come hither, speak softly, is thy daughter with child?

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: With child, Nibrassa?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Foe, do not trick me off, I overheard your gambling; hark in thine ear, so is mine too.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: Alas, my lord, by whom?

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Innocent by whom: what an idle question is that? One cock hath trod both our hens, Ferentes, Ferentes: who else? How dost take it? methinks thou art wondrous patient: why, I am mad, stark mad.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: How like you this, Colona, 'tis too true?
Did not this man protest to be your husband?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Ay me, to me he did.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: What else, what else, Petruchio? and madam, my quondam daughter, I hope h'aue passed some huge words of matrimony to you too.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Alas, to me he did.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: And how many more, the great incubus of hell knows best: Petruchio, give me your hand, mine own daughter in this arm, and yours, Colona, in this; there, there, sit ye down together; never rise, as you hope to inherit our blessings, till you have plotted some brave revenge: think upon it to purpose, and you shall want no seconds to further it, be secret one to another: come, Petruchio, let 'em alone, the wenches will demur on't, and for the process, we'll give 'em courage.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: You counsel wisely, I approve your plot:
Think on your shames, and who it was that wrought 'em.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ay, leave them alone: to work, wenches, to work. —

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: We are quite ruined.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: True, Colona,
Betrayed to infamy, deceived and mocked
By an unconstant villain; what shall's do?
I am with child.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Hey-ho, and so am I:
But what shall's do now?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This; with cunning words
First prove his love; he knows I am with child.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: And so he knows I am: I told him on't
Last meeting in the lobby, and in troth
The false deceiver laughed.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Now by the stars he did the like to me,
And said, 'twas well I was so haply sped.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Those very words
He used to me; it fretted me to'th heart:
I'll be revenged.
sp.stage: Enter Ferentes, and Morona an old lady.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Peace, here's a noise methinks :
Let's rise, we'll take a time to talk of this?

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.p: Will ye? hold: death of my delights, have ye lost all sense of shame? you're best roar about the court, that I have been your woman's-barber, and trimmed ye, kind Morona.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Defiance to thy kindness, thou'st robbed me of my good name, didst promise to love none but me, me, only me; swor'st, like an unconscionable villain, to marry me the twelfth day of the month, two months since; didst make my bed thine own, mine house thine own, mine, all and every thing thine own, I will exclaim to the world on thee, and beg justice of the Duke himself: villain, I will.

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.p: Yet again; nay, and if you be in that mood, shut up your fore-shop, I'll be your journeyman no longer: why wise madam Dryfist, could your mouldy brain be so addle, to imagine I would marry a stale widow at six and forty? Marry gip, are there not vareities enough of thirteen? come, stop your clap-dish, or I'll purchase a carting for you: by this light, I have toiled more with this tough carrion hen, then with ten quails, scarce grown into their first feathers.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: O treason to all honesty or religion, speak thou perjured-damnable-ungracious-defiler of women, who shall father my child which thou hast begotten?

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.p: Why thee, country woman; thou'st a larger purse to pay for the nursing: nay, if you'll needs have the world know how you, reputed a grave-matron-like motherly-madam, kicked up your heels like a jennet, whose mark is new come into her mouth, e'en do, do; the worst can be said of me is, that I was ill advised to dig for gold in a coalpit: are you answered?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Answered?

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.l: Let's fall amongst 'em, — love — how is't chick? ha.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: My dear Ferentes, my betrothed lord.

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.p: Excellent: o for three Barbary stone horses to top three Flanders mares? why how now wenches, what means this?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Out upon me, here's more of his trulls.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Love, you must go with me.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Good love, let's walk.

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.p: I must rid my hands of 'em, or they'll ride on my shoulders; by your leave, ladies: here's none but is of common counsel one with another: in short, there are three of ye with child, you tell me by me: all of you I cannot satisfy, (Nor indeed handsomely any of ye) you all hope I should marry you, which for that it is impossible to be done, I am content to have neither of ye; for your looking big on the matter, keep your own counsels, I'll not bewray ye; but for marriage, heaven bless ye, and me from ye; this is my resolution.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: How, not me!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Not me!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Not me!

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.p: Nor you, nor you, nor you.

And to give you some satisfaction, I'll yield you reasons: you, Colona, had a pretty art in your dalliance, but your fault was, you were too suddenly won; you, madam Morona, could have pleased well enough some three or four and thirty years ago, but you are too old; you, Julia, were young enough, but your fault is, you have a scurvy face; now every one knowing her proper defect, thank me, that I ever vouchsafed you the honour of my bed once in your lives: if you want clouts, all I'll promise, is to rip up an old shirt or two; so wishing a speedy deliverance to all your burdens, I commend you to your patience

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Notable.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Unmatched villain.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Madam, though strangers, yet we understand
Your wrongs do equal ours; which to revenge,
Please but to join with us, and we'll redeem
Our loss of honour, by a brave exploit.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I embrace your motion, ladies, with gladness, and will strive by any action to rank with you in any danger.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Come gentlewomen, let's together then,
Thrice happy maids that never trusted men. —
sp.stage: Enter Duke, Biancha supported by Fernando, Fiormonda, Petruchio, Nibrassa, Ferentes, and D'avolos.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Roseilli will not come then? will not? well,
His pride shall ruin him. — our letters speak
The Duchess uncle will be here tomorrow.
Tomorrow, D'avolos.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: Tomorrow night, my lord, but not to make more than one day's abode here: for his holiness has commanded him to be at Rome the tenth of this month, the conclave of Cardinals not being resolved to sit till his coming.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your uncle (Sweetheart) at his next return,
Must be saluted Cardinal: Ferentes,
Be it your charge to think on some device
To entertain the present with delight.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My lord, in honour to the court of Pavy,
I'll join with you: Ferentes, not long since,
I saw in Bruxils, at my being there,
The Duke of Brabant welcome the Archbishop
Of Mentz with rare conceit, even on a sudden
Performed by knights and ladies of his court,
In nature of an antic; which, methought ,
(For that I never before saw women antics)
Was for the newness strange, and much commended.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Now good my lord Fernando further this
In any wise, it cannot but content.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: If she entreat, 'tis ten to one the man
Is won before hand.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Friend, thou honour'st me:
But can it be so speedily performed?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I'll undertake it, if the ladies please
To exercise in person only that;
And we must have a fool, or such an one
As can with art well act him.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: I shall fit ye,
I have a natural.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Best of all, madam; then nothing wants:
You must make one, Ferentes.

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.l: With my best service and dexterity, my lord.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: This falls out happily, Nibrassa.

sp.speaker: Nib.
sp.l: We could not wish it better:
Heaven is an unbribed justice.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We'll meet our uncle in a solemn grace
Of zealous presence, as becomes the church:
See all the choir be ready, D'avolos.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: I have already made your highness' pleasure known to them.

sp.speaker: Bian
sp.l: Your lip, my lord!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Perhaps your teeth have bled, wiped with my handkercher; give me, I'll do't myself. — speak, shall I steal a kiss? believe me, my lord, I long.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Not for the world.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Apparent impudence.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: Beshrew my heart, but that's not so good.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ha, what's that thou mislikest D'avolos?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: Nothing, my lord, — but I was hammering a conceit of mine own, which cannot (I find) in so short a time thrive, as a day's practice.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: Well put off, secretary.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We are too sad, methinks the life of mirth
Should still be fed where we are;
Where's Maurucio?

sp.speaker: Feren
sp.p: An't please your highness, he's of late grown so affectionately inward with my lady marquess's fool, that I presume he is confident, there are few wise men worthy of his society, who are not as innocently harmless as that creature; it is almost impossible to separate them, and 'tis a question which of the two is the wiser man.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Would a were here, I have a kind of dulness
Hangs on me since my hunting, that I feel
As 'twere a disposition to be sick, my head is ever aching.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: A shrewd ominous token; I like not that neither.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Again! what is't you like not?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p:
I beseech your highness' excuse me; I am so busy
with his frivolous project, and can bring it to no shape, that it almost confounds my capacity.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: My lord, you were best to try a set at maw;
I and your friend, to pass away the time,
Will undertake your highness and your sister

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The game's too tedious.

sp.speaker: Fior.
sp.l: 'Tis a peevish play,
Your knave will heave the Queen out, or your King;
Besides, 'tis all on fortune.
sp.stage: Enter Maurucio, Roseilli like a fool, and Giacopo.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Bless thee, most excellent Duke; I here present thee as worthy and learned a gentleman, as ever I (And yet I have lived threescore years) conversed with; take it from me, I have tried him, and is worthy to be privy-counselor to the greatest Turk in Christendom: of a most apparent and deep understanding, slow of speech, but speaks to the purpose; come forward, sir, and appear before his highness in your own proper elements.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Will — tie — to da new toate sure la now.

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.p: A very senseless gentleman, and please your highness, one that has a great deal of little wit, as they say.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: O sir, had you heard him as I did, deliver whole histories in the Tangay tongue, you would swear there were not such a linguist breathed again; and did I but perfectly understand his language, I would be confident, in less than two hours, to distinguish the meaning of bird, beast, or fish, naturally, as I myself speak Italian, my lord. — well, he has rare qualities.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now prithee question him, Maurucio.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: I will, my lord.
Tell me, rare scholar, which in thy opinion,
Doth cause the strongest breath, — garlic or onion?

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.p: Answer him, brother fool; do, do, speak thy mind chuck, do.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Have bid seen all da fine knack, and d'ye
Naughty tattle of da knave, dad la have so.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We understand him not.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: Admirable, I protest, Duke; mark o Duke, mark!
What did I ask him, Giacopo?

sp.speaker: Gia.
sp.p: Which caused the strongest breath, garlic or onions, I take it, sir.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.p: Right, right by Helicon; and his answer is, that a knave has a stronger breath than any of 'em; wisdom (Or I am an ass) in the highest, a direct figure; put it down, Giacopo

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How happy is that idiot, whose ambition
Is but to eat, and sleep, and shun the rod:
Men that have more of wit, and use it ill,
Are fools in proof.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: True, my lord, there's many
Who think themselves most wise, that are most fools.

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.l: Bitter girds if all were known, — but —

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But what? speak out; plague on your muttering
Grumbling, I hear you, sir, what is't?

sp.speaker: R. D.
sp.p: Nothing, I protest, to your highness pertinent, to any moment.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Well, sir, remember. — friend, you promised study.
I am not well in temper; come Biancha,
Attend our friend Ferentes.
sp.stage: Exeunt. manent Fer. Ros. Feren. et Mau.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ferentes, take Maurucio in with you
He must be one in action,

sp.speaker: Feren.
sp.l: Come, my lord, I shall entreat your help.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I'll stay the fool:
And follow instantly.

sp.speaker: Mau.
sp.l: Yes, pray, my lord.

sp.speaker: Fer
sp.l: How thrive your hopes now, cousin?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Are we safe?
Then let me cast myself beneath thy foot,
True virtuous lord: know then, sir, her proud heart
Is only fixed on you in such extremes
Of violence and passion, that I fear,
Or she'll enjoy you, or she'll ruin you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Me, coz; by all the joys I wish to taste,
She is as far beneath thy thought, as I
in soul above her malice.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I observed
Even now, a kind of dangerous pretence
In an unjointed phrase from D'avolos:
I know not her intent, but this I know,
He has a working brain, is minister
To all my lady's counsels; and (My lord)
Pray heaven there have not any thing befallen
Within the knowledge of his subtle art,
To do you mischief.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Pish; should he or hell
